fr:title.text: Pointwise Kan extensions are computed by (co)limit formulae

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Pointwise Kan extensions are computed by (co)limit formulae

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A Kan extension with locally small codomains is pointwise if and only if it is computed by the (co)limit formula of the appropriate variance.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Category theory in context

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Suitable for advanced undergraduates and graduate students in mathematics, the text provides tools for understanding and attacking difficult problems in algebra, number theory, algebraic geometry, and algebraic topology. Drawing upon a broad range of mathematical examples from the categorical perspective, the author illustrates how the concepts and constructions of category theory arise from and illuminate more basic mathematical ideas. Prerequisites are limited to familiarity with some basic set theory and logic.

By the universal property of right Kan extensions, the right Kan extension of F along 1_C is F itself. Since this diagram is preserved by all functors, we conclude that this extension is pointwise, in which case (noting that c\downarrow 1_C = c/C) it is computed by the limit formula Fc\cong \operatorname *{lim}(c/C\xrightarrow {\Pi } C\xrightarrow {F} D). Now the result follows by the construction of limits from equalizers and products.

Let C\xrightarrow {F} E and C\xrightarrow {K} D be functors and suppose that the colimit \operatorname *{colim}(K\downarrow d\xrightarrow {\Pi _C} C\xrightarrow {F} E) exists for each d\in D. Then these colimits define the action on objects of the left Kan extension D\xrightarrow {\operatorname *{Lan}_K F} E, and furthermore the unit of the Kan extension is determined by the colimit cone.
Dually, the limits \operatorname *{lim}(d\downarrow K\xrightarrow {\Pi _C} C\xrightarrow {F} E) define the right Kan extension \operatorname *{Ran}_K F.

Let C\xrightarrow {F} E and C\xrightarrow {K} D be functors. Then a left Kan extension of F along K is a K^*-free object \operatorname *{Lan}_K F on F. Dually, a right Kan extension of F along K is a K^*-cofree object \operatorname *{Ran}_K F on F.

In other words, the universal property of a left Kan extension asks for a bijection E^C(F, GK)\cong E^D(\operatorname *{Lan}_K F, G) natural in D\xrightarrow {G} E: \operatorname *{Lan}_K F represents the functor E^D\xrightarrow {K^*} E^C\xrightarrow {\operatorname {Hom}(F, -)} Set.
A category C is locally small if for each pair of objects x and y, the collection C(x, y) forms a set.
